t: 2 Chronicles 6
Solomon’s Dedication of the Temple
Then*p Solomon said: The*pn Lord*s said he would dwell in total darkness,
but*ln I have built an exalted temple for you, a*ln place for your dwelling forever.
Then*p the king turned and blessed the entire congregation of Israel while they were standing.
He said: Blessed*pn be the Lord*s God of Israel! He*ln spoke directly to my father David, and*ln he has fulfilled the promise by*ln his power. He*ln said,

“Since*ln the day I brought my people Israel out*ln of the land of Egypt, I*ln have not chosen a city to build a temple in among*ln any of the tribes of Israel, so*ln that my name would be there, and*ln I have not chosen a man to*ln be ruler over my people Israel.
But*ln I have chosen Jerusalem so*ln that my name will be there, and*ln I have chosen David to*ln be over my people Israel.”
My*ln father David had his heart set on*ln building a temple for the name of the Lord,*s the God of Israel.
However,*ln the Lord*s said to my father David, “Since*ln it was your desire to build a temple for my name, you*ln have done well to have this desire.
Yet,*ln you are not the one to build the temple, but*ln your son, your own offspring, will*ln build the temple for my name.”

So*ln the Lord*s has fulfilled what he promised. I*ln have taken the place of my father David and*ln I sit on the throne of Israel, as the Lord*s promised. I*ln have built the temple for the name of the Lord,*s the God of Israel.
I*ln have put the ark there, where*ln the Lord’s*s covenant is that*ln he made with the Israelites.
Solomon’s Prayer
Then*p Solomon stood before the altar of the Lord*s in front of the entire congregation of Israel and spread out his hands.

For Solomon had made a bronze platform 7½ feet long, 7½ feet wide, and 4½ feet high and put it in the court. He stood on it, knelt down in front of the entire congregation of Israel, and spread out his hands toward heaven.
He said: Lord*spn God of Israel, there*ln is no God like you in*ln heaven or on earth, who*ln keeps his gracious covenant with*ln your servants who walk before you with*ln all their heart.
You*ln have kept what you promised to*ln your servant, my father David. You*ln spoke directly to him, and*ln you fulfilled your promise by your power, as*ln it is today.

Therefore,*ln Lord*s God of Israel, keep*ln what you promised to*ln your servant, my father David: “You*ln will never fail to have a man to*ln sit before me on the throne of Israel, if*ln only your sons take care to walk in my Law as*ln you have walked before me.”
Now,*ln Lord*s God of Israel, please confirm what*ln you promised to your servant David.
But*ln will God indeed live on earth with humans? Even*ln heaven, the highest heaven, cannot contain you, much*ln less this temple I have built.
Listen*ln to your servant’s prayer and his petition, Lord*sln my God, so*ln that you may hear the cry and the prayer that*ln your servant prays before you,

so*ln that your eyes watch over this temple day*ln and night, toward*ln the place where you said you*ln would put your name; and*ln so that you may hear the prayer your*ln servant prays toward this place.
Hear*ln the petitions of your servant and*ln your people Israel, which*ln they pray toward this place. May*ln you hear in your dwelling place in heaven. May*ln you hear and forgive.
If*ln a man sins against his neighbor and*ln is forced to take an oath and*ln he comes to take an oath before*ln your altar in this temple,

may*ln you hear in heaven and act. May*ln you judge your servants, condemning*ln the wicked man by bringing what*ln he has done on his own head and*ln providing justice for the righteous by*ln rewarding him according to his righteousness.

If*ln your people Israel are defeated before an enemy, because*ln they have sinned against you, and*ln they return to you and praise your name, and*ln they pray and plead for mercy before*ln you in this temple,
may*ln you hear in heaven and*ln forgive the sin of your people Israel. May*ln you restore them to the land you*ln gave them and their ancestors.

When*ln the skies are shut and there is no rain because*ln they have sinned against you, and*ln they pray toward this place and*ln praise your name, and*ln they turn from their sins because*ln you are afflicting them,

may*ln you hear in heaven and*ln forgive the sin of your servants and*ln your people Israel, so*ln that you may teach them the good way they*ln should walk in. May*ln you send rain on your land that*ln you gave your people for an inheritance.

When*ln there is famine in the land, when*ln there is pestilence, when*ln there is blight or mildew, locust or grasshopper, when*ln their enemies besiege them in*ln the land and its cities, when*ln there is any plague or illness,
every*ln prayer or petition that*ln any person or that all your people Israel may have — they*ln each know their own affliction and suffering — as*ln they spread out their hands toward this temple,
may*ln you hear in heaven, your dwelling place, and*ln may you forgive and give to everyone according*ln to all their ways, since you know each heart, for*ln you alone know the human heart,
so*ln that they may fear you and*ln walk in your ways all*ln the days they live on the land you*ln gave our ancestors.

Even*ln for the foreigner who is not of your people Israel but*ln has come from a distant land because*ln of your great name and*ln your strong hand and outstretched arm: when*ln he comes and prays toward this temple,

may*ln you hear in heaven in your dwelling place, and*ln do all the foreigner asks you. Then*ln all the peoples of the earth will know your name, to*ln fear you as your people Israel do and*ln know that this temple I have built bears*ln your name.

When*ln your people go out to fight against their enemies, wherever*ln you send them, and*ln they pray to you in*ln the direction of this city you have chosen and*ln the temple that I have built for your name,
may*ln you hear their prayer and petition in heaven and*ln uphold their cause.

When*ln they sin against you — for*ln there is no one who does not sin— and*ln you are angry with them and*ln hand them over to the enemy, and*ln their captors deport them to*ln a distant or nearby country,

and*ln when they come to their senses in*ln the land where they were deported and*ln repent and petition you in their captors’ land, saying,*ln “We have sinned and done wrong; we*ln have been wicked,”

and*ln when they return to you with all their mind and all their heart in*ln the land of their captivity where they were taken captive, and*ln when they pray in the direction of their land that*ln you gave their ancestors, and*ln the city you have chosen, and*ln toward the temple I have built for your name,
may*ln you hear their prayer and petitions in heaven, your*ln dwelling place, and*ln uphold their cause. May*ln you forgive your people who*ln sinned against you.
Now,*ln my God, please*ln let your eyes be open and*ln your ears attentive to*ln the prayer of this place.

Now*ln therefore: Arise,*ln Lord*s God, come to your resting place, you*ln and your powerful ark. May*ln your priests, Lord*s God, be clothed with salvation, and*ln may your faithful people rejoice in goodness.
Lord*sln God, do not reject your anointed one; remember*ln your servant David’s acts of faithful love.
